Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: I glanced at my phone between red lights, reading a message from my mentee: “I’m overwhelmed. Can we talk?” I’d noticed her slipping deadlines, her voice tight with stress during our last check-in. As her mentor, I wanted to help her untangle her schedule, to encourage her to find balance and confidence. But right now, I was behind the wheel, snow swirling outside, the city crawling under a heavy winter storm. My passenger in the back seat kept checking his watch, anxiety radiating from him. “I can’t miss this flight,” he said, voice urgent. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get him to the airport safely and on time, despite the treacherous roads. My mind tugged in two directions—one part wanting to pull over and call my mentee, to be the support she needed, the other focused on navigating icy streets and tense traffic, responsible for my passenger’s journey. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, and I felt the strain of being needed in two places at once.
